content.body:
> <@annevk:mozilla.org> tusf: it's a tree. Not aware of articles, but in the early days linked list vs array for representing children was a topic.

Gotcha. Thought I'd try experimenting with a document representation that was non-hierarchical, but I suppose that would need something outside the DOM (or a specialized extension of it; based on Ranges, perhaps?)
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:mozilla.org
tusf: it's a tree. Not aware of articles, but in the early days linked list vs array for representing children was a topic.
Gotcha. Thought I'd try experimenting with a document representation that was non-hierarchical, but I suppose that would need something outside the DOM (or a specialized extension of it; based on Ranges, perhaps?)

content.body: Benjamin Gruenbaum: FWIW, composing AbortSignal objects is still something we should do, but we need someone to do the work essentially :-)
content.formatted_body: Benjamin Gruenbaum: FWIW, composing AbortSignal objects is still something we should do, but we need someone to do the work essentially :-)

content.body: Benjamin Gruenbaum: there's also another tricky issue about making AbortSignal work well with timeouts, for which you really want to expose a cancel reason (or use a different exception, as XHR does)
content.formatted_body: Benjamin Gruenbaum: there's also another tricky issue about making AbortSignal work well with timeouts, for which you really want to expose a cancel reason (or use a different exception, as XHR does)

content.body: Jake Archibald: for the issue you just filed you haven't explained what an "isolated browsing context group" is
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: for the issue you just filed you haven't explained what an "isolated browsing context group" is

content.body: annevk: I thought it'd be obvious it's https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsers.html#cross-origin-isolation-mode, or do we have another form of isolation?
content.formatted_body: annevk: I thought it'd be obvious it's https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsers.html#cross-origin-isolation-mode, or do we have another form of isolation?

content.body: Okay, I was thinking it would be that, but I wasn't sure.
Jake Archibald: also is it intentional that it's first about bcg and later about bc?
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: also is it intentional that it's first about bcg and later about bc?

content.body: annevk: made some edits. Did I fix the bit you mean?
content.formatted_body: annevk: made some edits. Did I fix the bit you mean?

content.body: Jake Archibald: not the second question; the post seems to be about bcgs but the questions are about bcs
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: not the second question; the post seems to be about bcgs but the questions are about bcs

content.body: annevk: I thought it was impossible for a top level to change browsing context without also changing group?
content.formatted_body: annevk: I thought it was impossible for a top level to change browsing context without also changing group?

content.body: And a browsing context cannot exist in two groups
Jake Archibald: yeah that is correct, maybe I'm being too pedantic
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: yeah that is correct, maybe I'm being too pedantic

content.body: I'll add those points in as asserts ðŸ˜€
Added some clarifying text to question 1
Jake Archibald: so the main reason to care about bcg/bc identity is because of popups, right? Is there anything else you are concerned with here?
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: so the main reason to care about bcg/bc identity is because of popups, right? Is there anything else you are concerned with here?

content.body: Jake Archibald: question 2 is rather complex; I would not expect identity to be preserved if they are not visited in order (e.g., if you visit something else in between). As in, the traversal is what causes the swap and if you then traverse to non-isolated and then to isolated again, two more swaps.
content.formatted_body: Jake Archibald: question 2 is rather complex; I would not expect identity to be preserved if they are not visited in order (e.g., if you visit something else in between). As in, the traversal is what causes the swap and if you then traverse to non-isolated and then to isolated again, two more swaps.
